description: Now, the browser looks at the sizes attribute and thinks that the image always will be 375 pixels wide. As a result, it will load the most apropriate one, which of course is birthday_small.jpg. SmallFoot thinks that's fine on most phones, but he'd like the large one to be displayed on tablets and larger screens. As he understands it, he could add a media query which tells the browser that the image should be 1024px when the screen is at least 768px wide.
todo: Add a media query to the sizes attribute.

correct.headline: Success!
correct.text: The large image is only loaded on devices with a screen that's at least 768 pixels wide. Thanks to you, SmallFoot has learned how to use media queries in the sizes attribute!

wrong.headline: Something's not right...
wrong.text: If you're not careful, the site might load slow when SmallFoot sends the link to his friends. Make sure that the sizes attribute looks something like this: "(min-width: 768px) {LARGE-IMAGE-WIDTH}px, 375px"
